def tax_inclusive(P):
    return 'Exclusive' if P % 10 == 0 else 'Inclusive'

P = int(input())
print(tax_inclusive(P))

def tax(p):
    if p%10 == 0:
        return 'Inclusive'
    else:
        return 'Exclusive'

p = int(input())
print(tax(p))


This solution works by checking if the last digit of the input number is 0. If it is, then the MRP of the shoes is inclusive of taxes. If the last digit is not 0, then the MRP is exclusive of taxes.

def mrp(p):
    return 'Inclusive' if p % 10 == 0 else 'Exclusive'

p = int(input())
print(mrp(p))


This code will take the input value, check if it is divisible by 10 (i.e., the last digit is 0), and print 'Inclusive' if it is, and 'Exclusive' if it is not.

P = int(input())
if P % 10 == 0:
    print('Exclusive')
else:
    print('Inclusive')


This code works by reading the input integer P, then checking if the last digit of P is 0. If it is, the code prints 'Exclusive'. Otherwise, it prints 'Inclusive'.

The condition P % 10 == 0 checks if the last digit of P is 0, which is equivalent to checking if P is divisible by 10. This is because any number ending in 0 is divisible by 10.

So the code checks if the MRP of the shoes is exclusive or inclusive of taxes based on whether the MRP is divisible by 10.

Please note that this code assumes that the input is always a valid integer and does not handle any potential errors.
